newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Morning Update.

text.p: MASS MURDERER BRYANT IN COURT AGAIN
Port Arthur gunman Martin Bryant is in court again today in Hobart.
He'll appear before Mr Justice Bill Zeeman for a civil hearing in the Supreme Court under the Criminal Injuries Compensation Act.
The Director of Public Prosecutions, Damien Bugg, is seeking about one million dollars from Bryant under new Tasmanian laws, to help compensate victims of the Port Arthur shootings.
ANGER OVER HIGHER UNIVERSITY FEES
With the support of independent senators Brian Harradine and Mal Colston, the Senate last night passed the government's proposals for higher university fees.

Democrats senator, Natasha Stott-Despoja says she believes the pair was swayed by the Education Minister Senator Amanda Vanstone when she said university operating grants would be cut even further if the Senate didn't pass the proposals.
Senator Stott-Despoja says students have been sold out in a climate of fear, anxiety and blackmail.
The National Union of Students says it'll maintain the rage over the hike in fees by staging a long term campaign to try to make the education system more accessible and equitable.
DOCTOR DISGUSTED IN DEATH CERTIFICATE DELAY
The doctor of the first man to die using the Northern Territory's voluntary euthanasia law, says he's disgusted by the delay in the issuing of the death certificate.
The Office of the Coroner in Darwin says it can now proceed with issuing a death certificate for Bob Dent, who received a lethal injection in September.
The delay has concerned Doctor Philip Nitschke and Mr Dent's family.
The ABC has received a letter from the Territory's Deputy Coroner, confirming that until now, the cause of Mr Dent's death has been officially "unknown", pending an investigation.
The delay is blamed on the coroner not receiving certain documents from Dr Nitschke until a month ago, but Dr Nitschke says the process was simple enough not to have taken this long.
BLACKHAWK SURVIVOR CONSIDERS COMPO CLAIM
One of survivors from the Blackhawk helicopter collision is considering suing the defence force over his injuries.

Lance Corporal Gerry Bampton, an SAS trooper is a paraplegic as a result of the accident and six months after the mid-air collision, is still waiting to see if his home can be modified to suit his disability.
The Federal Government is currently conducting an inquiry into the adequacy of compensation.
Corporal Bampton says he'll wait for its finding in March next year before making his decision.
